results.title: Doctors' orders
results.creator_credit: Colin Richards and Granada International Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
After the publication of a report on prescribing in general practice, the program looks at the reasons for over-prescribing and talks to several general practitioners who feel they are being pressurised by both patients and drug companies into this expensive and potentially dangerous situation.

results.title: Doctor Zhivago
results.creator_credit: Carlo Ponti, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, United Artists Corporation and David Lean
results.brief_description: Doctor Zhivago is a moving story of love and romance told against the flaming background of the Russian Revolution. The story is presented through many characters whose destinies are interwoven. Not only is it a vast panorama of a country undergoing the most radical revolution in history; it also probes, with deep and desperate concern, the personal struggle of one man’s survival. The film stars Omar Sharif and Julie Christie. A poet, a surgeon, a husband and a lover - this is the story of Zhivago. Based on the novel by Boris Pasternak.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlo Ponti, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, United Artists Corporation and David Lean

results.title: Doctor woman: life and times of Elizabeth Bagshaw
results.creator_credit: Beryl Fox, Lockwood Films and Mark McCurdy
results.brief_description: A forerunner of the women’s movement, Elizabeth Bagshaw was one of the first women to practice medicine in Canada. In having to overcome society’s bias against women in medicine she helped to instigate changes in public opinion on that issue as well as the issue of birth control. The film captures the personality of this remarkable woman through a contemporary interview and re-enactments of episodes from her youth. The sepia tones of the re-enactments are in keeping with the film techniques of the time, giving the viewer a strong sense of the period. The film is of special interest to people interested in the evolution of woman’s roles in Canadian society. (Awards: Toronto; Columbus)

results.title: Doctor Who: the ark in space
results.creator_credit: Philip Hinchcliffe, BBC and Rodney Bennett
results.brief_description: The Doctor (Tom Baker), Sarah Jane Smith (Elisabeth Sladen) and Harry (Ian Marter) find themselves on space station Nerva - otherwise known as the Ark - where mission control appears to be sabotaged and all life forms have been cryogenically preserved in suspended animation. Sarah Jane finds herself one of the frozen chosen when she lies on a tranquilliser couch/short-range matter transmitter. When two of the Ark’s inhabitants are re-animated, med-tech Vira (Wendy Williams) and leader Noah (Kenton Moore) - they reveal that civilisation underwent mass cryogenic processing to avoid their imminent destruction by solar flares; the only problem being that their best laid plans for a programmed re-animation didn’t work due to their equipment being damaged by an unknown being. The unknown beings turn out to be The Wirrn, an insect race who have found a valuable food source on the Ark and laid it’s eggs on the solar stacks. It’s up to the Doctor to save the day. This was the second episode in which the fourth Doctor (Tom Baker 1974-1980) appeared. Originally broadcast in the UK on BBC1 between January 25 and April 15, 1975. Written by Robert Holmes.

results.title: Doctor Who: remembrance of the Daleks
results.creator_credit: John Nathan-Turner, British Broadcasting Corporation and Andrew Morgan
results.brief_description: The Doctor and Ace (Sophie Aldred) land in London, 1963, amidst an environment of mysterious magnetic fluctuation and a military stake out. Leaping in the back of scientific advisor Professor Rachel Jenson’s wagon, the time lord and his companion find themselves in the thick of a siege in which men are being killed by a mysterious “death ray”. The Doctor informs Group Captain Gilmore, the man in charge, that these are the energy weapons of the Daleks. The Daleks have come to retrieve something the first Doctor left behind at the school of his grand daughter Susan, the powerful Hand of Omega. The Daleks are species divided however, with two warring factions competing for the Hand. On one side there is Dalek Emperor Davros, on the other the renegade Imperial Dalek faction headed by the Supreme Dalek. The Doctor must stop the Daleks from gaining the Hand and protect Group Captain Gilmore and his men from extinction. Boasting more special Dalek induced effects than in previous episodes, Sylvester McCoy starred as the seventh Doctor in this 25th season of the cult series for a period of three years (1987-1989). Written by Ben Aaronovitch.

results.title: Doctor Jekyll and sister Hyde
results.creator_credit: Hammer, Albert Fennell, Brian Clemens and Roy Baker
results.brief_description: This unusual twist on Robert Louis Stevenson’s often filmed Doctor Jekyll and Mr Hyde also incorporates the Jack the Ripper mythology into it’s narrative. This time around the ‘good’ doctor Jekyll (Ralph Bates) is experimenting with female hormones in his quest for the elixir of youth, when things start to go horribly wrong. His experiment transforms him not into a hideous monster but a beautiful woman (Martine Beswick), giving the film an unexpected gender-bending twist. Of course the doctor spends much of his time in front of the mirror admiring his new breasts, while the upkeep of his new persona sends him into a grisly killing spree. Cast includes Gerald Sim, Lewis Fiander, Susan Broderick, Dorothy Alison.

results.title: Doctor Dolittle (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Arthur P. Jacobs, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Richard Fleischer
results.brief_description: This is a charming fantasy excursion which creates a wonderful world of endless imagination through music, dance and special effects. Rex Harrison stars in the madcap adventures of a 19th century English doctor who walks and talks and squarks with the animals. Based on the stories of Hugh Lofting, the good doctor gets himself into all sorts of funny predicaments in this fun film that earned an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture. With terrific music, fine acting, loveable creatures and a joyous fantasy tale, “Doctor Doolittle” is a classic for young and old alike.

results.title: Doctor De Soto and 5 other funny stories
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Michael Sporn and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s circle”.
A collection of animated short stories for children. “Doctor De Soto” by William Steig. The kind-hearted mouse Doctor De Soto is a dentist. He and his wife find a very clever way to treat a crafty fox, who comes to them with a sore tooth and secret thoughts of eating them after the job is done. This outstanding cartoon was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film. “Patrick” by Quentin Blake. When Patrick plays his fiddle, the countryside comes alive with vibrant colour and motion. “The Hat” by Tomi Ungerer. Penniless Benito finds good fortune when he comes upon a magic black hat with which he can perform fantastic feats. “Smile for Auntie” by Diane Paterson. Silly Auntie sings, dances, makes funny faces, stands on her head - anything to get the baby to smile! “The Foolish Frog” by Pete And Charles Seeger. Folk singer Pete Seeger plays and sings this catchy song about the frog who fell in the mud, to the delightful drawings of Mioslav Jagr. “Leopold the See-through Crumb-picker” by James Flora. Leopold is invisible and devours every crumb he finds, creating havoc in the process. See what happens when a little girl befriends him.

results.title: Doctor De Soto (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Michael Sporn
results.brief_description: Doctor De Soto, a mouse dentist, refuses to treat animals that are “dangerous” to mice, until one day a fox shows up writhing in pain from a toothache. How Doctor De Soto and his assistant, Mrs De Soto, “outfox the fox” is a humorous story.
